results.title: The Class
results.creator_credit: John Schlesinger, Huw Wheldon and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Monitor”.
A close-up of the work of a class in a drama school and of the methods used to train the aspiring actors and actresses. John Schlesinger’s command of the particular directing technique required is such that the film appears to have been made spontaneously during the forty minutes or so of the single class. In fact it needed a week’s shooting and a considerable amount of preparation in order to give this impression. The tutor (Harold Lang) uses the Mercy Speech from ‘The Merchant of Venice’ as a starting point in an improvisation by the students. Originally made for the BBC Television program ‘Monitor’, it is exciting to watch a production in the hands of a dedicated artist.

results.title: That's entertainment. Part 2
results.creator_credit: David Melnick, Saul Chaplin and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly cohost a stunning gallery of classic moments in MGM history. Features memorable performances by John Barrimore, Clark Gable, Greta Garbo and many others including the Marx Brothers, Abbot and Costello, Laurel and Hardy and the inimitable W C Fields. This video includes over ninety legendary superstars.

results.title: Clarinet and bass clarinet
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Basic Music Techniques”.
One of a series of films designed to assist the musician and the music lover. In this film professional musicians show how the clarinet and bass clarinet are played, demonstrate their range and tone, and show how to care for them.

results.title: A Day at the races
results.creator_credit: Sam Wood, Lawrence Weingarten and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A Marx Brothers movie combining humor and music. The plot, which shifts from a sanitorium to a race track, introduces a horse doctor masquerading as sanitorium director, a jockey who encourages his horse to win by showing it a picture of the man it hates, a vendor of bad racing tips and a vampire dressed in revealing clothing. Also stars Maureen O’Sullivan.

results.title: The Chosen
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Kagan, Edie Landau, Ely Landau and Chosen Film Company
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Chaim Potok which explores the friendship that develops between two adolescent Jewish boys living in New York in the 1940s. The boys are from vastly different Jewish backgrounds, one being an Hasidic Jew and the other a Zionist. Features Rod Steiger, Maximilian Schell as the boys fathers together with Robby Benson and Barry Miller.

results.title: The City
results.creator_credit: Falph Steiner, Willard Van Dyke and American Documentary Films
results.brief_description: An indictment of unplanned city growth and uncontrolled expansion of industry, this is one of America’s best documentary films, famous for its “eating sequence”. The film has three distinct sections: first, the early pastoral life of the American colonies; the chaotic and industrialised metropolis, the sprawling contrasting city, the dirt, poverty, ill health and despair of the victims of the industrial city’s haphazard growth; the necessity for planned city growth. Based on Lewis Mumford’s book, “The Culture of Cities”, this film owes much of its punch to the editing of well-chosen details, excellently photographed, enabling the film to argue visually.

results.title: Children on trial
results.creator_credit: Jack Lee, Basil Wright and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatic story (which shows incidentally some of the root causes of delinquency) showing the progress of a boy and, in less detail, a girl who are sent to an Approved School in Britain. The film gives an insight into the problems of the staff of these schools, and the difficulties which the children encounter at the school, in their efforts to make social adjustments; and finally, the life they face when their period at the school is finished.

results.title: Children of two worlds
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A child’s limited language ability can be a permanent bar to development in formal subjects. Looks at the problems of migrant children whose first language is not English, and the role of teachers in helping such children gain a thorough understanding and command of the English language. Suitable for tertiary/teacher education.

results.title: A Child went forth
results.creator_credit: John Ferno, Joseph Losey and New York University Film Library
results.brief_description: A study of an experimental nursery school for children between the ages of 2 and 7 years. The nursery school was founded during the war, when many parents were working and therefore unable to give their children the care the needed. It proved such a success that the school was continued after the war. The children were encouraged in those activities which helped to develop their self-reliance and independence. In close contact with nature, under conditions, as primitive as was consistent with safety, they learned how to live together, to develop self-discipline, to use their creative instincts in ways which yielded them satisfaction. The film relates the activities of this nursery school with more general techniques of progressive educational theory, and emphasises the potential value of such nursery-schools. Commentary written by Munro Leaf; narrated by Lloyd Gough.

results.title: Un Chien andalou
results.brief_description: A surrealistic film using symbolic objects and settings designed by Salvador Dali. The film was a collaboration between Bunuel and Dali over 3 days and shot in 2 weeks. A series of seemingly unrelated images are unified by their power to shock. The famed opening sequence was left out some releases by censors. Enthusiastically received by Paris surrealists, the film saw Bunuel and Dali being recognised by their peers, and it still enjoys its innovative arthouse status. Censorship restriction: Suitable only for adults.
